description: Customer Information System (CIS) has not received security patches since March 2023. Vulnerability scan identified 3 critical CVEs that could allow unauthorized access to billing data and payment systems for 7.2 million customers.

Supplier payment backlog of KES 8.5bn as at September 2024, including KES 3.2bn overdue to KenGen for power purchase obligations. Risk of service disruption if KenGen suspends supply under PPA default clause.

KPLC SAIDI performance of 38 hours per customer per year in FY2024 exceeds the EPRA minimum standard of 35 hours. If not improved to 35 hours by June 2025, EPRA may impose revenue clawback of up to KES 1.8bn per the regulatory framework.

High dependence on geothermal generation from Olkaria (contributing 42% of total supply) creates concentration risk. Any major outage at Olkaria would require expensive emergency thermal imports at up to 3x normal power purchase cost.

Foreign exchange exposure on USD-denominated loans totalling KES 38bn. KES/USD exchange rate depreciation of 15% in FY2024 added KES 5.7bn to loan balances. No formal forex hedging programme in place.
High voltage work-related accidents: 3 Lost Time Injuries (LTIs) recorded in H1 FY2024 including one fatality at Machakos substation during transformer replacement. OSHA investigation ongoing.

Nairobi CBD power blackout on 3 October 2024 affecting 420,000 customers for 7.75 hours received extensive negative media coverage and Parliamentary summons. Customer satisfaction index declined 8 points to 62%.

6 pending legal cases from contractors disputing contract terminations totalling KES 2.8bn in claimed damages. Risk assessment indicates KES 900m probable adverse outcome based on legal counsel opinion.

Technical and commercial losses (aggregate) at 22% of units distributed in FY2024, above the EPRA regulatory allowance of 18%. Excess losses of 4% represent unrecovered revenue of approximately KES 2.3bn annually.

Fuel hedging programme coverage expired 31 December 2024 with no renewal in place. At current Jet A-1 prices of KES 188/litre and unhedged consumption of 420 million litres, adverse price movement of 10% would represent a KES 1.8bn unfavourable variance versus budget.

Kenya Airways has negative equity of KES 36bn and debt/EBITDA ratio of 18x. Two lenders (Equity Bank and Standard Bank) have covenant breach provisions that could trigger acceleration of KES 12bn in debt if EBITDA does not reach KES 2bn by December 2024.

Average fleet age of 12.8 years (as at 2024) increasing maintenance costs. Three aircraft (2 B737-800 and 1 B777-300ER) are grounded awaiting heavy maintenance at a total cost of KES 2.8bn. Grounding reduces revenue-generating capacity by 9%.

Pilot fatigue incidents: 4 crew discretion (CDA) events reported in Q1-Q3 2024 where pilots declined to operate on fatigue grounds. While compliant with regulations, the frequency indicates crew scheduling deficiencies. KCAA has requested explanation.

CORSIA Phase 1 compliance — KQ's carbon emissions monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) system was deployed only in January 2024. 2023 baseline emissions data may not be fully captured, creating a risk of non-compliance penalties from ICAO.

Revenue leakage in code-share settlement reconciliation identified by Ernst & Young audit. Estimated unreconciled revenue of KES 320m from Air France-KLM, Delta, and Ethiopian Airlines code-share prorate settlements since 2022.

Pilot shortage risk — KQ has 18 unfilled B787 type-rated pilot vacancies due to global pilot shortage and competition from Gulf carriers offering 40% higher salaries. Risk of route suspensions if unfilled by Q1 2025.

Kenya Airways ranked 98th out of 100 in Skytrax 2024 African airline ranking. Social media sentiment analysis shows 62% negative sentiment primarily related to flight delays (average departure delay of 45 minutes) and baggage handling complaints.

Kilindini Channel silting — survey conducted in September 2024 shows channel depth reduced to 13.2m in 3 sections, below the minimum 14m required for fully laden Panamax vessels. Emergency dredging required before end of year at estimated cost of KES 850m.

Bunker oil spill of 12 tonnes in Kilindini Harbour on 15 July 2024 from MV Atlantic Star (Greek-registered). KPA Port Health Authority and NEMA investigating. Potential MARPOL penalties and clean-up costs estimated at KES 45m. Civil liability exposure from fishermen claims.

KRA has raised a tax assessment of KES 420m relating to VAT on port handling charges for FY2021-2023, claiming exemption should not apply. KPA has filed an objection with the Tax Appeals Tribunal. Risk of adverse ruling requiring payment plus 2% monthly interest.

3 of 12 ship-to-shore gantry cranes are beyond their 25-year design life and require replacement by 2026. Failure of any crane during peak operations would reduce berth productivity by 25% and risk vessel diversions to Dar es Salaam.

Workplace accident rate of 4.2 per 1,000 employees in FY2024 (industry benchmark: 2.5). Three serious injuries in stevedoring operations involving crane operations. OSHA audit scheduled for December 2024.

Drought conditions reducing hydro generation capacity from Tana River cascade by an estimated 35% in FY2025. Emergency thermal imports required at 3x normal cost, with estimated additional power purchase cost of KES 4.2bn if dry conditions persist to June 2025.

Ethiopian Airlines has increased Nairobi-London and Nairobi-Amsterdam frequencies to twice daily, directly competing with KQ's core long-haul routes. KQ market share on Europe routes declined from 38% to 31% in 12 months.

Proposed East African Community Tripartite Port Policy changes could require KPA to adopt uniform pilotage fee schedules with Dar es Salaam Port, potentially reducing KPA pilotage revenue by KES 280m annually.
